Executive Summary

The City of Rosenberg (herein referred to as the City) owns a municipal wastewater treatment plant (WWTP 1A) in Rosenberg, Fort Bend County, Texas, which has a quantity of chlorine that exceeds the RMP threshold.  WWTP 1A also has sulfur dioxide; however, the RMP threshold for sulfur dioxide is not exceeded; therefore, sulfur dioxide is not included in this RMP submittal.  WWTP 1A is operated by Southwest Water Company (SWWC), a private company.

The City and SWWC has reviewed its obligations under EPA's Risk Management Program Rule (RMP Rule, Section 112? of the Clean Air Act).  In response to these requirements, the City and SWWC note the following obligations incumbent on the operations at the chlorine disinfection unit (also referred to as the chlorinator unit) at WWTP 1A:
(1) 112?(1) - Purpose and General Duty Clause - The essence of the general duty clause is that an owner/operator that stores and uses hazardous chemicals in any quantity has a fundamental obligation to ensure a safe operation, and to have plans in place in the event of an accident to appropriately manage the situation.  The City and SWWC take this obligation seriously, and intend to be not only a good neighbor but also a leader in community safety and emergency preparedness. 
(2) Risk Management Plan - SWWC operates WWTP 1A, which stores and uses chlorine in excess of the threshold specified in the RMP Rule. SWWC has developed, and is in the process of further developing and implementing, programs to prevent any accidental releases and training for emergency response in the event of a release.  These programs are documented and described in this Risk Management Plan.

The purpose of the chlorine water treatment process is to treat and disinfect municipal wastewater. Chlorine is delivered as a compressed gas in one-ton cylinders, and there are typically two cylinders stored at WWTP 1A at any one time.
